steps.text: Construct buildings with preventive design for pest management.
Maintain building to prevent pest entry.
Implement daily pest management programs.
Maintain records.
Address pests from facility and surrounding areas.
Follow federal and state regulations.
Design building for pest prevention.
Maintain short grass and trimmed shrubs.
Install paved access and proper drainage.
Create an 18- to 24-inch gravel strip around the foundation.
Place night-lights at least 30 feet away from doors.
Keep framing at least four inches from walls.
Fill necessary voids with materials like polyurethane foam.
Use concrete or brick walls that are sealed and easy to clean.
Seal hollow panel-type walls.
Use smooth, free-standing water roofs.
Limit the number of windows.
Use transparent glass block for windows.
Install metal and tight-fitting doors.
Use air curtains at large doors.
Install good lighting with dust-tight fixtures.
Install electrical and plumbing services for easy access and cleaning.
Make control panels insect-proof.
Eliminate litter, waste, and uncut grass.
Pave dusty roads and maintain lawns.
Ensure proper drainage.
Position lighting away from buildings.
Reduce bird harborage and outside food spillage.
Use rodent, insect, and bird traps.
Maintain housekeeping and implement pest monitoring programs.
Maintain bait stations for rodent management.
Use insecticidal baits and approved insecticides near breeding sites.
Use chemical repellents and avicides where appropriate for bird management.
Rodent-proof all openings.
Screen windows.
Block bird access to ledges.
Locate equipment off the floor or sealed to it.
Inspect all incoming vehicles and materials.
Store materials away from walls for inspection access.
Use rodent traps near doors and map their locations.
Use air curtains at doors.
Use deterrents for birds on roosting sites.
Implement a detailed monitoring program and a total facility IPM program.
Use rodent traps near doors if needed.
Ensure proper sanitation.
Use space treatments with nonresiduals, crack and crevice treatments with residuals, spot treatments, and fumigation for raw commodities.
Form an inspection committee and assign roles.
Conduct a thorough inspection of the plant.
Record all defects and distribute notes to department heads.
Departments correct identified defects.
Committee reviews notes, addresses uncorrected items, and assigns correction dates.
Sanitation is the responsibility of everyone in the plant.
Inspect areas using a flashlight to detect insect trails or mouse footprints.
Observe suspect stock by spreading it on a flat surface and watching for movement.
Inspect areas most likely to produce results, such as under and inside equipment.
Suspect any unaccounted-for voids in equipment or structures.
Observe employee actions and in-plant practices.
Reward good sanitation to encourage plant-wide cooperation.
Consider periodic inspections by an outside firm for a fresh perspective.
Check temperature drop can cause high mortality.
Implement good sanitation and temperature control.
Minimize insect movement by inspecting incoming materials.
Design buildings to minimize entry points.
Use visual inspection for monitoring.
Consider using yellow or sodium arc lights outdoors.
Place pheromone-baited traps in high-risk areas.
Examine trends in trap catches over time.
Identify common insect pests in raw grain and processed food.
Select appropriate trap types based on the environment.
Place traps on the outer perimeter of a facility for interception and prediction.
Monitor trap catches for increases in numbers from one period to the next.
Implement a pest management plan, including monitoring and inspection, building modifications, non-chemical control, and chemical control.
Read the label carefully before using any pesticide.
Understand food-handling establishment areas: food, food processing facilities, nonfood areas, and food areas.
Apply pesticides according to their labels: general applications (nonfood areas), spot applications (limited areas), or crack and crevice applications (food areas).
Follow pesticide regulations at the federal and state levels.
Identify life cycle stages of beetles and moths: egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
Understand that beetle larvae do not have legs on the back half of their body.
Recognize that adult beetles have chewing mouthparts and feed on various food sources.
Identify moth species: Almond Moth, Indianmeal Moth, Mediterranean Flour Moth, Mealmoth.
Check for signs of moth infestation in food products.
Identify beetle species: Lesser Grain Borer, Cigarette Beetle, Drugstore Beetle, Confused Flour Beetle, Sawtoothed Grain Beetle, Merchant Grain Beetle, Foreign Grain Beetle, Rusty Grain Beetle.
Inspect food products for signs of beetle infestation.
Implement control measures: Avoidance, sanitation, heat treatment, cold treatment, residual insecticides, space sprays, fumigation.
Identify pests: Spider Beetles, Warehouse Beetle / Dermestid Beetles, Cockroaches, Flies, Ants, Bees and Wasps, Booklice.
Determine pest characteristics: appearance, behavior, preferred habitats, signs of infestation.
Implement control measures based on pest type: sanitation, residual pesticides, dusts, contact sprays, nest treatment.
Monitor and evaluate effectiveness of control measures.
Identify pest species: Silverfish, Firebrats, Crickets, Ground Beetles, Sowbugs and Pillbugs, Rats, or Mice.
Understand pest behavior: senses, reactions, agility.
Recognize signs: droppings, runways, rubmarks, burrows, tracks, urine.
Implement rodent management: sanitation and habitat modification, rodent-proof construction.
Use compressed air sprayer for crack and crevice, spot, and general sprays.
Fill the tank with appropriate pesticide.
Clean hose, valve, and nozzle after each use.
Check gaskets and valves regularly.
Never leave pressurized equipment unattended.
Choose appropriate nozzle for spray pattern.
Maintain dusters by keeping them clean and dry.
Follow instructions for using space treating equipment.
Wear appropriate respiratory protection as needed.
Perform daily negative and positive pressure checks.
Wash respirators regularly.
Store respirators in a clean, protected place.

constraints.text: Use IPM approach integrating chemical, physical, cultural, and biological controls.
Thorough inspections must be conducted in all areas of the plant.
Require an 18-inch space between pallets and walls for inspection in warehouses.
A written inspection procedure for incoming raw products is required by law.
Implement temperature control and good sanitation to slow pest growth.
Minimize insect movement by inspecting incoming materials and designing buildings.
Match trap types to the environment (dusty vs. clean, hot vs. cold).
Detect pests and adjust trap placement or add more traps.
Ensure that pesticides are used in accordance with their labels to maintain regulatory compliance.
Ensure proper application of pesticides only to approved sites as per label instructions.
Maintain a safe working environment by considering potential interactions with facility practices before application.
Check for signs of moth or beetle infestation before consuming food products.
Store food products in airtight containers to prevent infestations.
Ensure proper identification of pests before implementing control measures.
Follow safety guidelines when handling pesticides and treating nests.
Understand pest behavior before implementing control measures.
Maintain clean facilities to minimize rodent presence.
Ensure equipment is safe and effective by following maintenance procedures.
Use appropriate nozzle for desired spray pattern.
Follow safety guidelines when using space treating equipment.
Wear appropriate respiratory protection as indicated on the label.
